"Now it turns out, one of his earliest supporters is a man named Bill Ayers," Palin said.
 
 "Boooo!" said the crowd.
 
 "And, according to the New York Times, he was a domestic terrorist and part of a group that, quote, 'launched a campaign of bombings that would target the Pentagon and our U.S. Capitol,'" she continued.
 
 "Boooo!" the crowd repeated.
 
 "Kill him!" proposed one man in the audience. 
 
 Palin went on to say that "Obama held one of the first meetings of his political career in Bill Ayers's living room, and they've worked together on various projects in Chicago." Here, Palin began to connect the dots. "These are the same guys who think that patriotism is paying higher taxes -- remember that's what Joe Biden had said. And" -- she paused and sighed -- "I am just so fearful ...."
 
 "Boooo!" said the audience.
 
 http://voices.washingtonpost.com/the..._the_roug.html 
 
 
 So a threat is made against a presidential candidate's life in the presence of a rabble-rousing demagogue, the media, but most importantly, police and secret service personnel, ............................ and nothing happens.

Palin has just opened the door for Keating 5, and who knows what else, scandal involving John McCain to resurface. That is, if Obama doesn't just take it lying down like John Kerry did. She also opened the door to her witchdoctor exercism and other smut that's floating around out there.
 
 It's going to get nasty. McCain has no other choice. So much for his word to run a clean campaign. emoticon_xdonno
 
 But Americans have every right to know these things about the candidates. Truthfully, they both have enough mud sling to keep us all happy for the next month or so.
 
 However, I would like to see Senator McCain come out and make these accusations from the podium rather than sending a girl out to do his dirty work. Also, I predict Palin will be thrown under the "straight talk" bus after the campaign is over. She's done. emoticon_cry
 
 Personally, I think his approach will come back and bite him in the butt later. Obama's numbers are still on the rise regardless of the attack ads. By all indicators, short of a GOP miracle, Obama will be our next president and several GOP candidates will be losing their seats as well.
 
 When McCain goes back to the Senate and Palin goes back to govern Alaska, they would be fools to think that Barack Obama will just forgive and forget the fact that they have accused him of "paling around" with terrorists. Neither will the Obama supporters, who happen to be the majority of Americans at this point in time.
 
 But, I suppose, drastic times call for drastic measures. The stocks have dropped over 700 points AGAIN today (so far.) 
 
 Whatever McCain has to do to keep the attention off of that amongst the masses, he's gotta do. I just hate to see a man with such high regard and a lifetime of honorable integrity go down in a gutter trash way. He deserved better.

Your hyperbole is predictable and completely theatrical.
 
 Please bear in mind that McCain's participation in the Keating Five was not equal to that of the other members named. There were four Democrats and one Republican investigated. The investigation showed that McCain and John Glenn were not improper in their actions.
 
 http://www.slate.com/id/1004633/
 
The Senate Ethics Committee probe of the Keating Five began in November 1990, and committee Special Counsel Robert Bennett recommended that McCain and Glenn be dropped from the investigation. They were not. McCain believes Democrats on the committee blocked Bennett's recommendation because he was the lone Keating Five Republican.
 
 In February 1991, the Senate Ethics Committee found McCain and Glenn to be the least blameworthy of the five senators. (McCain and Glenn attended the meetings but did nothing else to influence the regulators.) McCain was guilty of nothing more than "poor judgment," the committee said, and declared his actions were not "improper nor attended with gross negligence." McCain considered the committee's judgment to be "full exoneration," and he contributed $112,000 (the amount raised for him by Keating) to the U.S. Treasury.

 
 Your Keating Five argument is very weak considering the FACTS surrounding the investigation. To paint McCain along with those who truly acted improperly is nothing more than an example of your deliberate bias. It has little to do with reality.

Absolutely correct. There's another thread here that deals with that. Of course, the Bush haters completely ignore history and blame the sound bite..."Bush's failed economic policies".
 
 Jimmy Carter started it with CRA of 1977. Clinton made it even easier to get loans in the hands of voters that couldn't pay. The greed and corruption from both sides of the aisle, coupled with little regulation and no reform after it was recognized that some was needed (Bush, McCain and others saw it coming) caused the meltdown of the housing market.
